Title:
New anatomical data and phylogenetic relationships of
Chebsaurus algeriensis (Dinosauria, Sauropoda) from the Middle Jurassic
of Algeria.
Keywords:
Algeria; Dinosauria; Ksour Mountains; Middle Jurassic;
Sauropoda
Abstract:
New osteological details of the sauropod Chebsaurus
algeriensis form the Middle Jurassic Aïssa Formation of the Naama
Province, Algeria, are presented. The described material belongs to two
junvenile individuals. Recent field work has provided new cranial and
post-cranial material. This new material presents a combination of
plesiomorphic and apomorphic eusauropod characters adding more data to
the skull and post-cranial skeletal morphology. A phylogenetic analysis
(237 characters, 39 taxa: 16 parsimonious trees of 479 steps, CI = .53,
RI-.73) (Läng 2008) indicates an unsolved phylogenetic position of
Chebsaurus within the non-neosauropod Eusauropoda. Indeed, Chebsaurus is
positioned in a multifurcuration with Middle Jurassic ‘cetiosaurids’
Lapparentosaurus madagascariensis, Ferganasaurus verzilini, Cetiosaurus
mogrebiensis, and Cetiosaurus oxoniensis from Oxford. This polytomy
could be explained by numerous missing data and also from evolutive
radiation that might have succeeded the extinction at the end of the
Early Jurassic (Pliensbachian - Toarcian) and/or the Pangea
break-up.
